description: Borrowed from Latin immersus, from immergō, from in + mergō.

adjectives.description: immerse (comparative more immerse, superlative most immerse)

verbs.description: immerse (third-person singular simple present immerses, present participle immersing, simple past and past participle immersed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place within a fluid (generally a liquid, but also a gas).
examples: ... the two plates of platinum immersed in oxygen and hydrogen gases
The sculptor immersed himself in anatomic studies.

entries.meaning: (transitive, mathematics) To map into an immersion.
examples: Thus, in mathematical terms a Klein bottle cannot be "embedded" but only "immersed" in three dimensions as an embedding has no self-intersections but an immersion may have them.
